positive: But for regular productivity and creative work, ExpertBook is more than enough, plus it’s super light and the battery backup is great.
So yes, very good slim light laptop overall, 15.3" screen size is perfect too, though I hope these spinning wheel, fan noise, trackpad issues are all software related and get a quick fix from Lenovo.

I have looked for reviews of the hp, but I have not seen the exact model, so if any of you have used this laptop and can tell me what the build quality is like or think that one of the other laptop is better I would appreciate the help.
negative: its $1,100 [Acer Aspire Go 15.6-in Laptop, Ryzen 7 5825U– 32GB RAM, 1TB SSD]( - its $800 on SALE right now, but the build quality, screen, everything seems very limited, not to say its a bad laptop but it doesn't seem like its gonna last a long time.
All IPS panels have IPS glow, but this one has the worst case of glow I've ever seen.
But the computer isn't perfect and i've noticed a few issues which make me hesitant to go down the repair route with Lenovo for a second time so early into ownership.

negative: its $1,100 [Acer Aspire Go 15.6-in Laptop, Ryzen 7 5825U– 32GB RAM, 1TB SSD]( - its $800 on SALE right now, but the build quality, screen, everything seems very limited, not to say its a bad laptop but it doesn't seem like its gonna last a long time.

Only con is that it's pretty expensive, but at least it comes with 32GB 1TB, not 16GB 512GB like the M4 MBP at the same price (but M4 should perform much MUCH better, and last much longer, but no OLED, no touchscreen, no upgradable storage, no WiFi7, etc).
The missing fingerprint scanner, weak speakers, plastic interior, and lack of a stylus on all models really hold it back.
